cards.title: Football Weekly: Barcelona write themselves into history
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly: Barcelona write themselves into history

item.title: Football Weekly: Barcelona write themselves into history
item.trailText: Champions League glory for Barça. Plus: the Women's World Cup and our predictions for next season in an end-of-term extravaganza
item.standFirst: Champions League glory for Barça. Plus: the Women's World Cup and our predictions for next season in an end-of-term extravaganza
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
Well, gang, it's the final Football Weekly of the season, and AC Jimbo has Barry Glendenning, Paolo Bandini and John Ashdown choking back the tears, and Sid Lowe on the phone providing the hankies.

We start of course in Berlin where Barcelona won their second treble and fourth Champions League trophy in a decade. Does that make Luis Enrique Pep 2.0 or is he actually the new Roberto Di Matteo? And what of Juventus – who will be staying at, retiring from or leaving the Old Lady? Questions, listeners, questions …

Next, we speak to our newest friend, Caroline Barker, about the opening weekend of the Women's World Cup in Canada.

And finally, we gaze into our crystal balls to make a few bald-faced predictions for the 2015-16 season.

It's been a blast and thank you for being along for the ride once again. We'll be putting out some special treats over the summer, so keep refreshing your iTunes feed and all that gubbins.

And if you're quick, you can still get yourself a ticket for this very excellent (but Jimbo-free) Guardian Fifa debate.

displayImages.caption: Supporting images for Champions League final: Barcelona have written history again, says Luis Enrique - video Photograph: guardian.co.uk
displayImages.altText: Supporting images for Champions League final: Barcelona have written history again, says Luis Enrique - video
displayImages.cleanCaption: Supporting images for Champions League final: Barcelona have written history again, says Luis Enrique - video

cards.title: Football Weekly Live: Sepp Blatter falls on his sword as Fifa crisis deepens
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly Live: Sepp Blatter falls on his sword as Fifa crisis deepens

item.title: Football Weekly Live: Sepp Blatter falls on his sword as Fifa crisis deepens
item.trailText: In an exclusive excerpt from our recent live event in Manchester, the podders reflect on Sepp Blatter's resignation and the ongoing crisis at Fifa
item.standFirst: In an exclusive excerpt from our recent live event in Manchester, the podders reflect on Sepp Blatter's resignation and the ongoing crisis at Fifa
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
Greetings all, and welcome to a special mini-pod, featuring the most broadcast-friendly bits from our recent Football Weekly Live in Manchester event, in which AC Jimbo, Iain Macintosh, Barry Glendenning and James Horncastle wax lyrical about the Fifa crisis and Sepp Blatter's decision to step down.

We'll be back on Monday with the final pod of the season, looking back on the Champions League final and a few other highlights and lowlights from the last nine months. See you then.

• Comments are off for (Fifa) moderation purpose, but available on our liveblog.

displayImages.caption: FIFA President Sepp Blatter leaves after a press conference. Photograph: Valeriano Di Domenico/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: FIFA President Sepp Blatter leaves after a press conference.
displayImages.cleanCaption: FIFA President Sepp Blatter leaves after a press conference.

cards.title: Football Weekly: Arsenal thrash Aston Villa as Fifa farce rumbles on
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly: Arsenal thrash Aston Villa as Fifa farce rumbles on

item.title: Football Weekly: Arsenal thrash Aston Villa as Fifa farce rumbles on
item.trailText: Arsenal retain the FA Cup, Sepp Blatter lives to fight another day, and a preview of the Champions League final
item.standFirst: Arsenal retain the FA Cup, Sepp Blatter lives to fight another day, and a preview of the Champions League final
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
It's the penultimate Football Weekly of the season, and with Amy Lawrence, Jacob Steinberg and John Ashdown alongside AC Jimbo, we're going out with something of a bang.

We begin with that ridiculously one-sided FA Cup final where Arsenal absolutely tonked Aston Villa to retain the trophy.

Next, Owen Gibson tells us about his wild week in Zurich at Fifa's annual congress. You may have read about what went on.

Finally, Filippo Maria Ricci – an Italian covering Spanish football – gives us his unique take on Juventus taking on Barcelona in Saturday's Champions League final.

Congratulations by the way to listeners and posters Andrew Pinel and New Buildings who correctly predicted that Arsenal would win 4-0 at Wembley. Signed copies of Amy's excellent book Invincible will be on their way to you just as soon as you email Producer Ben your address. No timewasters, please.

displayImages.caption: Theo Walcott of Arsenal celebrates after scoring his side's first goal during the FA Cup final against Aston Villa. Photograph: Tom Jenkins
displayImages.altText: Theo Walcott of Arsenal celebrates after scoring his side's first goal during the FA Cup final against Aston Villa.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Theo Walcott of Arsenal celebrates after scoring his side's first goal during the FA Cup final against Aston Villa.

cards.title: Football Weekly: Norwich up, Hull down and Brendan Rodgers on the brink
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly: Norwich up, Hull down and Brendan Rodgers on the brink

item.title: Football Weekly: Norwich up, Hull down and Brendan Rodgers on the brink
item.trailText: The podders look back on a dramatic final weekend in the Premier League and Football League play-offs. Plus: Carlo Ancelotti is sacked by Real Madrid, and a preview of the Europa League final
item.standFirst: The podders look back on a dramatic final weekend in the Premier League and Football League play-offs. Plus: Carlo Ancelotti is sacked by Real Madrid, and a preview of the Europa League final
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
On today's special Tuesday edition of Football Weekly, AC Jimbo is joined in the pod by Barry Glendenning, Rafa Honigstein and John Ashdown to reflect on a surprisingly dramatic final weekend in the Premier League. Newcastle survived, Hull didn't, Big Sam walked away from West Ham – but perhaps the biggest news was that Liverpool's 6-1 capitulation away at Stoke may prove to be Brendan Rodgers' swansong. Outstanding!

Next up, Paul MacInnes shares his joy at Norwich City's triumph in the Championship play-off final. The Canaries weren't the only ones to win at Wembley, so we give the requisite shout-outs to Preston and Southend too.

Finally, we look forward to the Europa League final, and – because we're not here on Thursday – we also preview the FA Cup final.

We'll be joined next Monday by Amy Lawrence and because her book Invincible – all about Arsenal's unbeaten season back in the dark ages – has just come out in paperback, we're running a mini-competition. All you have to do is correctly predict the score of the Arsenal-Aston Villa game at Wembley, write it in the comments below, and you'll win a signed copy of the book. Woof!

See you Monday.

displayImages.caption: Supporting images for Norwich City joy after Championship win against Middlesbrough secures Premier League spot  video Photograph: guardian.co.uk
displayImages.altText: Supporting images for Norwich City joy after Championship win against Middlesbrough secures Premier League spot  video
displayImages.cleanCaption: Supporting images for Norwich City joy after Championship win against Middlesbrough secures Premier League spot  video

cards.title: Football Weekly Extra: Sunderland secure their safety
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly Extra: Sunderland secure their safety

item.title: Football Weekly Extra: Sunderland secure their safety
item.trailText: Podcast: The Black Cats stay up after drawing at Arsenal - so will it be Newcastle or Hull who drops out of the Premier League? Plus, Raheem Sterling prepares to leave Liverpool, and more match-fixing in Italy
item.standFirst: The Black Cats stay up after drawing at Arsenal - so will it be Newcastle or Hull who drops out of the Premier League? Plus, Raheem Sterling prepares to leave Liverpool, and more match-fixing in Italy
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
Yes listeners, it's the final Football Weekly Extra of the season, but don't be a Dick (Advocaat) and shed a solitary tear: AC Jimbo, Barry Glendenning, Iain Macintosh and Simon Burnton are here to take away your troubles.

Speaking of which, Sunderland confirmed their place in next season's Premier League relegation battle by getting the single point they required at Arsenal. That means it'll be either Hull - who travel to Manchester United - or Newcastle - at home to West Ham - who'll be joining Burnley and QPR in the Championship next season. All will be revealed on Sunday.

Also in the podcast, we react to Raheem Sterling's attempts to extricate himself from Liverpool and Brendan Rodgers, and we speak to Paolo Bandini about a typical week in Italy: another match-fixing scandal, offensive comments about women's football by a senior member of the country's football federation, and another trophy for Juventus.

Finally, we look ahead to the Richest Game in Football™ as Norwich take on Middlesbrough at Wembley. Seeing as that games takes place on Monday, we'll be delaying next week's show until Tuesday morning, but with Rafa Honigstein and John Ashdown joining us, it's well worth the wait.

Thanks by the way to everyone who bought a ticket to our forthcoming live show in Manchester. We are now officially sold old. Woof!

displayImages.caption: Supporting images for Sunderlands Dick Advocaat refuses to be drawn on future at the club after avoiding Premier League relegation  video Photograph: guardian.co.uk
displayImages.altText: Supporting images for Sunderlands Dick Advocaat refuses to be drawn on future at the club after avoiding Premier League relegation  video
displayImages.cleanCaption: Supporting images for Sunderlands Dick Advocaat refuses to be drawn on future at the club after avoiding Premier League relegation  video

cards.title: Football Weekly: a hell of a week for Hull
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly: a hell of a week for Hull

item.title: Football Weekly: a hell of a week for Hull
item.trailText: Relegation looms for Hull. Plus, Barcelona win La Liga; Norwich set up play-off final with Middlesbrough; and the definitive Football Weekly A to Z
item.standFirst: Relegation looms for Hull. Plus, Barcelona win La Liga; Norwich set up play-off final with Middlesbrough; and the definitive Football Weekly A to Z
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
Well, listeners, the end is in sight, and on today's Football Weekly, AC Jimbo has Barry Glendenning, Jonathan Wilson and Paul MacInnes doing their damndest to make sure it doesn't end just yet.

We start with the final piece of the relegation jigsaw. Hull occupy the dreaded 18th place going in to the final weekend, having had a shocking week both on and off the pitch. Newcastle, meanwhile, went down 2-1 at QPR. If only Middlesbrough and Norwich could replace them both …

Away from the Premier League, we compile the Football Weekly A to Z, covering everything from the A League to Zenit St Petersburg's league triumph. We'll need your help please, listener, to fill in the blanks.

Finally, we hear from Sid Lowe about Barcelona's title triumph and the latest on David de Gea's much-mooted move to Real Madrid.

We're back on Thursday, and remember, if you live in Manchester, we'll be doing another of our infamous live shows on Wednesday 3 June. Get your hands on the last few tickets here.

displayImages.caption: Dejection for Hull City. Photograph: Julian Finney/Getty Images Photograph: Julian Finney/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Dejection for Hull City
displayImages.cleanCaption: Dejection for Hull City. Photograph: Julian Finney/Getty Images

cards.title: Football Weekly Extra: Juventus book their place in the Champions League final
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly Extra: Juventus book their place in the Champions League final

item.title: Football Weekly Extra: Juventus book their place in the Champions League final
item.trailText: Podcast: Juventus hold firm against Real Madrid. Plus, a preview of the weekend in the Premier League, including Steven Gerrard's final Anfield hurrah
item.standFirst: Juventus hold firm against Real Madrid. Plus, a preview of the weekend in the Premier League, including Steven Gerrard's final Anfield hurrah
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
On this rip-roaring edition of Football Weekly Extra, James Richardson is joined by Jacob Steinberg, James Horncastle and Barry Glendenning to marvel at plucky Juventus, who held Real Madrid to a draw and thus booked their passage to Berlin and a Champions League final with Barcelona. Woof!

Next, we gaze ahead to the relegation battle in the Premier League and Steven Gerrard's teary farewell at Anfield. Double woof!

Once again, there's plenty of other stuff in the show, but we'd rather point you in the direction of the full audio of Barry's interview with Chris 'Kammy' Kamara and to where you buy the last few tickets to Football Weekly Live in Manchester.

Jonathan Wilson will be with us on Monday, so post your pseud-tastic questions on the blog below.

displayImages.caption: Gianluigi Buffon celebrates. Photograph: Javier Soriano/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Gianluigi Buffon celebrates.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Gianluigi Buffon celebrates.

cards.title: Football Weekly: QPR and Burnley relegated
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly: QPR and Burnley relegated

item.title: Football Weekly: QPR and Burnley relegated
item.trailText: Podcast: The podders wave goodbye to the Rs and the Clarets. Plus, can Bayern overturn a 3-0 deficit against Barcelona in the Champions League?
item.standFirst: The podders wave goodbye to the Rs and the Clarets. Plus, can Bayern overturn a 3-0 deficit against Barcelona in the Champions League?
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
On today's Football Weekly, AC Jimbo is joined by Barry Glendenning, Philippe Auclair and Michael Hann to bid adieu to QPR and Burnley, who are heading straight back to the Championship. Will they be missed? Will they bounce back? And who will be the final team joining them in the ignominy of Premier League relegation? Questions, listener, questions.

Next up, we hear from Rafa Honigstein about those pesky Pep-to-City rumours, and the prospects of Bayern Munich coming up with another second-leg turnaround in their Champions League semi-final with Barcelona.

There's plenty more in the show, but frankly we're much more interested in plugging our upcoming live show in Manchester on 3 June. Woof!

displayImages.caption: QPR, who were relegated after losing to Manchester City, have vowed to fight any FFP fines. Photograph: BPI/REX Shutterstock/Matt West Photograph: BPI/REX Shutterstock/Matt West
displayImages.altText: Clint Hill
displayImages.cleanCaption: QPR, who were relegated after losing to Manchester City, have vowed to fight any FFP fines. Photograph: BPI/REX Shutterstock/Matt West

cards.title: Football Weekly Extra: Leo Messi at the double as Barcelona batter Bayern
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly Extra: Leo Messi at the double as Barcelona batter Bayern

item.title: Football Weekly Extra: Leo Messi at the double as Barcelona batter Bayern
item.trailText: It's an unhappy return to Camp Nou for Pep Guardiola as Bayern Munich go down 3-0 to Barcelona. Plus, will it finally be curtains for Burnley and QPR?
item.standFirst: It's an unhappy return to Camp Nou for Pep Guardiola as Bayern Munich go down 3-0 to Barcelona. Plus, will it finally be curtains for Burnley and QPR?
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
Your pod is fit to bursting for today's Football Weekly Extra, with AC Jimbo joined by Jacob Steinberg, Barry Glendenning, James Horncastle, Iain Macintosh and even Sid Lowe to look back on a chastening homecoming for Pep Guardiola with his Bayern side. Will the Germans come back from a 3-0 deficit against Messi and co? And – with Juventus leading against Real Madrid – will this year's Champions League final provide a nice reunion for Luis Suárez and his old pals Patrice Evra and Giorgio Chiellini?

Having dealt with Europe, we turn our attention to the Premier League. Will Sunderland beat Everton and put even more pressure on Newcastle, who will probably lose their ninth game in a row at home to West Brom. And what of Burnley and QPR – is this the weekend when mathematics replaces hope and they make a swift return to the Championship?

We're back on Monday with added Philippe Auclair and Michael Hann – but much more exciting than that is the news that we're heading up the motorways for a special end o'season spectacular. Yes – Football Weekly will be live in Manchester on the evening of Wednesday 3 June. All the info you need is here.

displayImages.caption: Bayern Munich coach Pep Guardiola looks dejected as Barcelona celebrate. Photograph: Kai Pfaffenbach/Reuters Photograph: Kai Pfaffenbach/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Bayern Munich coach Pep Guardiola looks dejected as Barcelona celebrate
displayImages.cleanCaption: Bayern Munich coach Pep Guardiola looks dejected as Barcelona celebrate. Photograph: Kai Pfaffenbach/Reuters

cards.title: Football Weekly: Chelsea crowned champions as Newcastle go into meltdown
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly: Chelsea crowned champions as Newcastle go into meltdown

item.title: Football Weekly: Chelsea crowned champions as Newcastle go into meltdown
item.trailText: Chelsea win the Premier League title with three games to spare. Plus, Newcastle's losing run continues; Pep Guardiola's return to Barcelona; and the ups and downs in the Football League
item.standFirst: Chelsea win the Premier League title with three games to spare. Plus, Newcastle's losing run continues; Pep Guardiola's return to Barcelona; and the ups and downs in the Football League
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
Well folks, it's all over. Against all the odds, Chelsea have won the Premier League title for the first time in plucky José Mourinho's second spell in charge at the club, and on today's Football Weekly, AC Jimbo is joined by Rafa Honigstein, John Ashdown and Ian McCourt to celebrate their much predicted triumph.

With the title race done and dusted, our attention thusly turns to the relegation battle and Newcastle's utter implosion under John Carver. Will they ever pick up a point again, and will anyone shed a tear if they do end up going down to the Championship?

Speaking of the Championship, we run down the final tables in said division and Leagues One and Two, before hitting the big time and previewing the Champions League semi-finals between Barcelona and Bayern Munich and Real Madrid and Juventus.

Enjoy the rest of your bank holiday, and remember kids – don't forget to vote.

displayImages.caption: Jose Mourinho, manager of Chelsea, Chelsea v Crystal Palace Photograph: IPS/REX Shutterstock/Rex Features Photograph: IPS/REX Shutterstock/Rex Features
displayImages.altText: Jose Mourinho thumbs up
displayImages.cleanCaption: Jose Mourinho, manager of Chelsea, Chelsea v Crystal Palace Photograph: IPS/REX Shutterstock/Rex Features

cards.title: Football Weekly Extra: Bournemouth, ostriches and the rise of Carpi
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly Extra: Bournemouth, ostriches and the rise of Carpi

item.title: Football Weekly Extra: Bournemouth, ostriches and the rise of Carpi
item.trailText: AC Jimbo returns as the podders discuss Bournemouth's imminent promotion to the Premier League, Nigel Pearson's bizarre ostrich rant, and the minnows of Carpi reaching Serie A
item.standFirst: AC Jimbo returns as the podders discuss Bournemouth's imminent promotion to the Premier League, Nigel Pearson's bizarre ostrich rant, and the minnows of Carpi reaching Serie A
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
AC Jimbo is back from his sojourn with over-muscled men, and on today's Football Weekly Extra, it's a case of brains not brawn as he holds court with Jacob Steinberg, Barry Glendenning and James Horncastle.

We begin with Nigel Pearson's peculiar but nonetheless spectacular ostrich-themed rant, following Chelsea's 3-1 victory over his Leicester side, and was possibly more entertaining than much of the Blues' performances on their march to the Premier League title.

Next, with a bit of help from Scott Anthony, we discuss Bournemouth's imminent ascension to the big time, and look forward to the final weekend in the Football League.

Finally, because we know you've missed it, there's a bumper European section to send you off into the weekend, which includes the tale of woe at Milan and remarkable rise of Carpi to Serie A.

We'll have Rafa Honigstein in the pod on Monday, so leave your questions for him on the blog below.

displayImages.caption: Eddie Howe, third from left, celebrates with his Bournemouth players after the win over Bolton all but secured their promotion to the Premier League. Photograph: Clive Rose/Getty Images Photograph: Clive Rose/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Eddie Howe, third from left, celebrates with his Bournemouth players after the win over Bolton
displayImages.cleanCaption: Eddie Howe, third from left, celebrates with his Bournemouth players after the win over Bolton all but secured their promotion to the Premier League. Photograph: Clive Rose/Getty Images

cards.title: Football Weekly: Leicester's late leap to safety continues
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly: Leicester's late leap to safety continues

item.title: Football Weekly: Leicester's late leap to safety continues
item.trailText: Podcast: The podders react to Leicester's win at Burnley and the rest of the results at the top and bottom of the Premier League. Plus, Watford promoted, Tranmere relegated, and the latest from the Women's Super League
item.standFirst: The podders react to Leicester's win at Burnley and the rest of the results at the top and bottom of the Premier League. Plus, Watford promoted, Tranmere relegated, and the latest from the Women's Super League
item.byline: Max Rushden
item.body:
It's Max Rushden's final show at the helm of Football Weekly, and on today's show he's brought Barry Glendenning, John Ashdown and BBC 5live's Caroline Barker along for the ride.

We begin in the Premier League. Chelsea's draw at Arsenal as good as wrapped up the title, but at the bottom things are getting very exciting, with Leicester notching up a fourth win in a row leaving Burnley marooned at the foot of the table.

Next we head to the Championship and praise Watford's promotion - but who will join them in the top tier, and which two of Wigan, Rotherham or Millwall will join Blackpool in League One next season?

Finally, we sing an ode to Tranmere, relegated from the Football League after a 94-year stay, and get a rather comprehensive round-up on everything in the world of women's football.

Jimbo is back from his time with over-muscled men and returns on Thursday!

displayImages.caption: The Leicester City manager, Nigel Pearson, celebrates  with Wes Morgan after the 1-0 win at Burnley Photograph: Matt West/BPI/Rex Shutterstock Photograph: Matt West/BPI/Rex Shutterstock
displayImages.altText: Nigel Pearson Leicester City
displayImages.cleanCaption: The Leicester City manager, Nigel Pearson, celebrates  with Wes Morgan after the 1-0 win at Burnley Photograph: Matt West/BPI/Rex Shutterstock

cards.title: Football Weekly Extra: Bayern Munich rip up the record books
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly Extra: Bayern Munich rip up the record books

item.title: Football Weekly Extra: Bayern Munich rip up the record books
item.trailText: The podders analyse Bayern's masterclass as they pummelled Porto in the Champions League quarter-final. Plus, a look ahead to Arsenal v Chelsea, Burnley v Leicester and more
item.standFirst: The podders analyse Bayern's masterclass as they pummelled Porto in the Champions League quarter-final. Plus, a look ahead to Arsenal v Chelsea, Burnley v Leicester and more
item.byline: Presented by Max Rushden and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
Max Rushden returns to the pod with his BFF Barry Glendenning and NBFs Iain Macintosh and Jacob Steinberg for your Extraaaaa dose of Football Weekly.

We begin with the Champions League, and Bayern Munich's trouser-splitting brilliance as they ripped up the records books and overturned a 3-1 deficit to utterly tonk Porto. Sid Lowe tells us how the Spanish press reacted to Pep's performance, as well as Barcelona's swatting aside of PSG, and Real's last-gasp victory over Atlético Madrid.

Next, we turn our attention to the Premier League, especially the six-pointers at the top and bottom. As Chelsea travel to Arsenal, we ask whether there is a final twist in the title race, and having decided that there probably isn't, we instead ponder Burnley's fate as they host Leicester.

Finally, there's more on Scottish football, the anti-Ashley protests at Newcastle, and even a definitive guide to handwashing.

Max will be back on Monday, Jimbo returns next Thursday...

displayImages.caption: Pep Guardiola with ripped trousers gives his Bayern Munich players instructions during the thrashing of Porto. Photograph: Christof Stache/AFP/Getty Images Photograph: Christof Stache/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Pep Guardiola with ripped trousers gives his Bayern Munich players instructions during the thrashing of Porto.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Pep Guardiola with ripped trousers gives his Bayern Munich players instructions during the thrashing of Porto. Photograph: Christof Stache/AFP/Getty Images

cards.title: Football Weekly: tricky Villa set up FA Cup final with Arsenal
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly: tricky Villa set up FA Cup final with Arsenal

item.title: Football Weekly: tricky Villa set up FA Cup final with Arsenal
item.trailText: Aston Villa see off Liverpool to book their return to Wembley. Plus, Leicester continue to claw their way towards safety, Watford top the Championship, and Celtic are stunned by Inverness
item.standFirst: Aston Villa see off Liverpool to book their return to Wembley. Plus, Leicester continue to claw their way towards safety, Watford top the Championship, and Celtic are stunned by Inverness
item.byline: Presented by Max Rushden and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
Max Rushden begins his residency in near-earth orbit, and on today's Football Weekly he's joined by Barry Glendenning, Amy Lawrence and John Ashdown to look back on a splendid weekend of football.

We begin at Wembley where Aston Villa out-tactic-ed Liverpool and Arsenal squeezed past Reading to set up the FA Cup final in May. But never mind the glory and the trophies – what now for Brendan Rodgers? Is he soon for the exit at Liverpool?

Next, we turn our attention to the relegation scrap in the Premier League. West Brom got a vital win against Crystal Palace and Leicester continued their mini-revival, but Newcastle are in free-fall. Will the Magpies pull themselves out of trouble (and do they deserve to)?

Finally, we look ahead to the return legs of the Champions League quarter-finals and make one of our all-too-rare sojourns to Scotland to catch up on the fitba north of the border.

displayImages.caption: Christian Benteke of Aston Villa celebrates after Fabian Delph of Aston Villa scored their second. Photograph: Ian Walton Photograph: Ian Walton/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Christian Benteke of Aston Villa celebrates after Fabian Delph of Aston Villa scored their second.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Christian Benteke of Aston Villa celebrates after Fabian Delph of Aston Villa scored their second. Photograph: Ian Walton

cards.title: Football Weekly Extra: Jürgen Klopp calls time in Dortmund
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly Extra: Jürgen Klopp calls time in Dortmund

item.title: Football Weekly Extra: Jürgen Klopp calls time in Dortmund
item.trailText: The podders react to Klopp's decision to leave BVB. Plus: Porto stun Bayern in the Champions League; FA Cup semi-final previews; and Bristol City promoted
item.standFirst: The podders react to Klopp's decision to leave BVB. Plus: Porto stun Bayern in the Champions League; FA Cup semi-final previews; and Bristol City promoted
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
AC Jimbo welcomes Jacob Steinberg, Paul Doyle and Paolo Bandini to the pod for today's Football Weekly Extra, which comes to you in its tightest and most tasteful lederhosen as we embrace our German side and focus on Jürgen Klopp's announcement that he's quitting Dortmund at the end of the season. How nice then that we could track down Rafa Honigstein too to help us with the translation.

Next up, we analyse the first legs of the Champions League quarter-finals, not least Bayern's tonking in Porto, before turning our attention to the weekend's action in the FA Cup semi-finals and the Premier League.

Finally, we provide out latest missive on the promotion picture in the Championship and raise a glass of cider to Bristol City, who won't be slumming it in League One next season.

Not wishing to urinate on your French fries, but this is Jimbo's last pod for a bit as he heads over to Malaysia and another rip-roaring World's Strongest Man tournament. Max Rushden will be holding the fort for the next three shows. Be gentle …

displayImages.caption: Jürgen Klopp appears lost for words at the press conference revealing his decision to leave Borussia Dortmund – not that it mattered  much to the Daily Telegraph’s Ben Bloom. Photograph: Alexandre Simoes/Borussia Dortmund/Getty Images Photograph: Alexandre Simoes/Borussia Dortmund/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Jurgen Klopp
displayImages.cleanCaption: Jürgen Klopp appears lost for words at the press conference revealing his decision to leave Borussia Dortmund – not that it mattered  much to the Daily Telegraph’s Ben Bloom. Photograph: Alexandre Simoes/Borussia Dortmund/Getty Images

cards.title: Football Weekly: Manchester City left red raw by United
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly: Manchester City left red raw by United

item.title: Football Weekly: Manchester City left red raw by United
item.trailText: Podcast: United humble City in the Manchester derby. Plus, Leicester continue their revival as Sunderland and Hull hit the skids
item.standFirst: United humble City in the Manchester derby. Plus, Leicester continue their revival as Sunderland and Hull hit the skids
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
On today's Football Weekly, AC Jimbo has Barry Glendenning, Paul MacInnes and Michael Cox on board to assess all the action from the top and bottom of the Premier League.

We begin at Old Trafford, where Manchester United did the serious do on City. What now for Manuel Pellegrini and fast-fading squad of underachievers?

At the other end of the table meanwhile, Sunderland put on another horror show, at home to Crystal Palace, giving hope to Leicester, who may not be dead and buried after all.

Finally, we catch up with things in the Championship, and speak to Sid Lowe in Spain ahead of the Champions League quarter-finals.

All in all, quite the show, wouldn't you say?

displayImages.caption: Chris Smalling scores the 4th United goal during the Manchester derby, winning 4-2 at Old Trafford. Photograph: Tom Jenkins Photograph: Tom Jenkins/the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Chris Smalling scores the 4th United goal during the Manchester derby, winning 4-2 at Old Trafford.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Chris Smalling scores the 4th United goal during the Manchester derby, winning 4-2 at Old Trafford. Photograph: Tom Jenkins

cards.title: Football Weekly Extra: the fight to stay in the Premier League
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly Extra: the fight to stay in the Premier League

item.title: Football Weekly Extra: the fight to stay in the Premier League
item.trailText: The pod preview the weekend's matches across Europe, including an in-depth look at the battle to stay in the Premier League
item.standFirst: The pod preview the weekend's matches across Europe, including an in-depth look at the battle to stay in the Premier League
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Peter Sale
item.body:
James Richardson is joined by Barry Glendenning, Paul Doyle and Philippe Auclair to look forward to this weekend's matches.

With QPR, Burnley and Leicester looking like they have some fight left, the pod wonder which teams could get dragged into the bottom three. Could this be the year that the lowest points total ever keeps you up? There's a full preview of Premier League games with QPR v Chelsea and Burnley v Arsenal looking particularly tasty. And that's before we even get to the Manchester derby.

The pod squad also get stuck into: Liverpool's FA Cup win over Blackburn, the Championship promotion race, PSG still hoping to do the quadruple in France and Gabon landing the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations.

As always, leave your comments below. See you next week.

displayImages.altText: Aston Villa's Christian Benteke scores his third goal in the Premier League match against QPR
displayImages.cleanCaption: Aston Villa's Christian Benteke scores his third goal in the Premier League match against QPR. Photograph: John Sibley/Action Images via Reuters

cards.title: Football Weekly: Arsenal thrash Liverpool
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly: Arsenal thrash Liverpool

item.title: Football Weekly: Arsenal thrash Liverpool
item.trailText: The pod discuss a weekend of extraordinary goals in the Premier League and ask what's going wrong for Brendan Rodgers and Liverpool
item.standFirst: The pod discuss a weekend of extraordinary goals in the Premier League and ask what's going wrong for Brendan Rodgers and Liverpool
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Peter Sale
item.body:
Barry Glendenning, James Horncastle and Jacob Steinberg join host James Richardson to wrap up the weekend's football action.

On a weekend which saw several remarkable goals scored, the pod decide Bobby Zamora's wonder-chip for QPR against WBA is their favourite, but also give big props to Charlie Adam and an emotional Jermaine Defoe.

Liverpool's season was looking good a couple of weeks ago, but after two successive defeats, the pod ask if the problems can be fixed. They do likewise with the ongoing nightmare at Leeds United.

There's a full European round-up with news of a big win for PSG in France, a turf-throwing incident at Celta Viga, and more unpleasantness in the Roma v Napoli game.

Leave your comments for us below.

displayImages.caption: Mesut Özil scores Arsenal's second goal against Liverpool in the Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. Photograph: Julian Finney/Getty Images Photograph: Julian Finney/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Mesut Özil scores Arsenal's second against Liverpool in the Premier League at the Emirates Stadium
displayImages.cleanCaption: Mesut Özil scores Arsenal's second goal against Liverpool in the Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. Photograph: Julian Finney/Getty Images

cards.title: Football Weekly Extra: the Premier League returns for its final furlong
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly Extra: the Premier League returns for its final furlong

item.title: Football Weekly Extra: the Premier League returns for its final furlong
item.trailText: The podders wave goodbye to the international break, and look ahead to the return of the Premier League – including Arsenal v Liverpool and the Wear-Tyne derby
item.standFirst: The podders wave goodbye to the international break, and look ahead to the return of the Premier League – including Arsenal v Liverpool and the Wear-Tyne derby
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
On today's Football Weekly Extra, AC Jimbo is joined by Barry Glendenning, James Horncastle and debutant Nick Miller to wave goodbye to international football until June, and give the warmest of welcomes to the Premier League, which gets back to business this Easter weekend.

Everything is still up for grabs, at both ends of the table. Arsenal could go second if they beat Liverpool at the Emirates, a result which could end Liverpool's Champions League aspirations – and lead to a hasty meeting between Raheem Sterling's team and Brendan Rodgers. At the other end of the table, Sunderland's survival chances will be greatly improved by a fifth successive victory over Newcastle. Will Big Dick Advocaat get his side up for the Tyne-Wear derby?

Toodles.

displayImages.caption: The Premier League Trophy Photograph: David Levene Photograph: David Levene/David Levene
displayImages.altText: The Premier League Trophy
displayImages.cleanCaption: The Premier League Trophy Photograph: David Levene

cards.title: Football Weekly: Wales and Northern Ireland remain on course for Euro 2016
cards.rawTitle: Football Weekly: Wales and Northern Ireland remain on course for Euro 2016

item.title: Football Weekly: Wales and Northern Ireland remain on course for Euro 2016
item.trailText: Podcast: The home nations impress in the Euro 2016 qualifiers. Plus, more Q and A, and a snippet from our live show
item.standFirst: The home nations impress in the Euro 2016 qualifiers. Plus, more Q and A, and a snippet from our live show
item.byline: Presented by James Richardson and produced by Ben Green
item.body:
Once more into the breach we go, podders, as AC Jimbo, John Ashdown, Ian McCourt and the returning Barry Glendenning tackle the international break.

It was a weekend full of cheer for the home nations – and Ireland – as all remain in the hunt for Euro 2016 qualification, not least England, Wales and Northern Ireland. Which is nice.

Having sated ourselves with all that, we turn our attention once more to your questions, and as a special treat, we've even got an extract from our Football Weekly Live in London event, which took place last Friday night.

Enjoy!

displayImages.caption: Gareth Bale celebrates after scoring the second goal for Wales. Photograph: Matthew Childs Photograph: Matthew Childs/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Gareth Bale celebrates after scoring the second goal for Wales.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Gareth Bale celebrates after scoring the second goal for Wales. Photograph: Matthew Childs
